item.title: Congratulations to Hossam Hassan Sultan for successfully defending his PhD!
item.description: After answering three hours of questions from Prof Steven Freear (external examiner) and Prof Perry Xiao (internal examiner) on ultrasound, cortical bone and data processing, Hossam Hassan Sultan passed his PhD examination. Thank you to both examiners and special thanks to Prof Mohammad Ghavami for chairing the examination.

item.description: Great presentation by Hossam Hassan Sultan on exploring the role of ultrasound signals, envelope features with the application of machine learning algorithms for bone health monitoring.

item.title: New research grant awarded by the MRC.
item.description:
Speed Ultrasound Lab won a new research grant, funded by the Medical Research Council (MRC) to develop new drug delivery technology to the brain. The problem with cancer drugs, or chemotherapy in general, is that drugs kill the health tissue along with the tumour. Our technology, which is a combination of microwaves and ultrasound, will be able to activate the cancer drugs on demand, only at desired locations inside the brain to minimize the collateral damage.

A total of £155.9k is awarded for this research project ‘Enhancing Blood-Brain Barrier Opening with Ultrasound and Microwaves for Targeted Drug Delivery’.

item.title: Dr Harput joins the editorial board of the Frontiers in Acoustics.
item.description: Pleased to join the editorial board of Frontiers in Acoustics as review editor. This new journal will help drive innovation in its field through high quality open access research. Find out more: https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/acoustics

item.title: We are teaching ultrasound imaging for the world's first anthroengineeing course.
item.description: A completely new academic course, MSc Anthroengineering, which for the first time brings together Engineering (science of technology) and Anthropology (science of humanity) has been started. Click here for more…. Dr Harput is teaching the physics and applications of medical imaging modalities, especially ultrasound imaging.

item.title: Fully Funded & Industry Sponsored PhD Scholarship in Ultrasonic Testing and Data Analysis for Nuclear Industry
item.description:
We are offering an industrial PhD scholarships funded by the National Nuclear Laboratory and the Sellafield Ltd, which manages the nuclear fuel reprocessing, nuclear waste storage and nuclear decommissioning. The industrial partners expect the PhD project to develop into a real world product, where the successful PhD candidate will be able to lead the project beyond the PhD timeline.

Click here for details.

item.title: Apply for a PhD in ultrasound and microwave dual-modality imaging.
item.description: PhD scholarships available in dual-modality cancer therapy with ultrasound and microwaves using nanodroplets. The aim of this research project is to develop a novel therapeutic method by combining ultrasound and microwave imaging modalities to activate nanodroplets. The PhD project will focus on characterization of novel therapeutic nanodroplets using ultrasound and microwaves. PhD student will work closely with the Prof M Thanou’s research team at King’s College London, who are developing the nanodroplets. Click here for details.

item.title: Realistic Bone Simulations for Ultrasonic Characterization of Cortical Bone Porosity and Thickness
item.description:
To establish a more realistic model, cortical bone simulations were generated using microstructural elements extracted from a real micrograph. Then, the new extracted pores have been used as seeds to build a reference dictionary. For the extracted pores, many features have been calculated and considered such as the effective diameters, pore sizes, and pores geometrical shapes. By employing this dictionary, numerous numbers of new cortical bone maps could be generated.

In realsitic simulations, pores are randomly distributed within the cortical bone to mimic different biological conditions. In addition, geometric distortions have been added and considered including bone curvature, surface roughness, and pore-density weighting along the lateral-medial or anterior-posterior direction.

Research project: ‘Ultrasonic bone characterization’.

item.title: Fully funded industrial PhD position available.
item.description:
PhD scholarship available in Ultrasonic Non-Destructive Testing: https://www.findaphd.com/phds/program/phd-scholarship-in-ultrasonic-non-destructive-testing-for-nuclear-applications/?i152p5453

The successful candidate will develop an ultrasonic analysis tool for detecting hydrogen gas in sealed pressurised storage containers. This project is fully funded by the National Nuclear Laboratory. The post will also offer a job opportunity in the nuclear sector at the end of the PhD period. Please contact Dr Sevan Harput by email for more details.

item.title: New Ultrasound Bone Quantification Project
item.description:
Sevan Harput – “A New Non-Invasive Technique for Bone Porosity Imaging”
Event: BioMedical Imaging at LSBU: A Vision of the Future in Imaging Technology
Organiser: London South Bank University
Date & Time: June 8, 2021 (10:20)


Join us to take the next step with your business and learn about the cutting edge developments in the area of BioMedical Imaging and Image Processing. The speakers will discuss successes in research, collaboration and commercialisation – in the areas of Ultrasound, Microwave Ultrawide Band Imaging, Infrared sensing and applications of machine vision and deep learning all to increase the quality of patient outcomes.

A total of £20k is awarded for this research project ‘Human Ear-inspired Ultrasonic Transducer (HEUT) with a Spiral-shaped Acoustic Lens for 3D Localization of Sparse Scatterers’.

item.title: Seminar on 4 February 2020 at the Institute of Cancer Research (ICR), London, UK.
item.description: Dr Harput is invited to give a seminar on ‘Super-Resolution Ultrasound Imaging with Microbubble Contrast Agents: Challenges and Opportunities’ at the Institute of Cancer Research (ICR), London, UK.

item.title: Dr Harput is invited to the ‘Leaders in Innovation Fellowship’ networking event, London, UK.
item.description:
Dr Harput has been invitated by Ambassador Ümit Yalçın, for “Leaders in Innovation Fellowship” networking event that he will be hosting on Tuesday, 28th January 2020 at the Ambassadorial Residence.

The Leaders in Innovation Fellowships (LIF) programme, which is run by the Royal Academy of Engineering and supported by the Newton Fund, works with engineers, academics and researchers in 16 countries, who have an innovation that could have a positive social or economic impact in their own countries or other developing nations. 15 participants from each country are chosen to attend an intensive 2-week entrepreneurship training course in London followed by up to a year of one-to-one support in their home countries to build their capacity to bring their innovations to market. There is a global community of over a thousand innovators working across a wide range of engineering disciplines and sectors tackling complex global challenges, including medical technology, agrotechnology and food security, water and sanitation, sustainable energy, and data infrastructure.

item.title: Minister of Education (United Arab Emirates) and Executive Vice President (Khalifa University) visited LSBU.

item.title: Our abstract has been accepted for the 25th European symposium on Ultrasound Contrast Imaging 2020 in Rotterdam, NL.
item.description: Our abstract on ‘Micro vessel Analysis with 3D Super-resolution Ultrasound and Super-Resolved Velocity Mapping’ has been accepted as an oral presentation for the competition: SUPER-RESOLUTION IMAGING. It will be presented by Dr Matthieu Toulemonde at the 25th European symposium on Ultrasound Contrast Imaging 2020 in Rotterdam, NL.

item.title: Attending the IEEE International Ultrasonics Symposium (IUS) 2019 in Glasgow, UK.
item.description:
We did not forget to present our research, while catching up with friends and colleagues in Glasgow, UK.

Here are our proceedings:

Acoustic Wave Sparsely-Activated Localization Microscopy (AWSALM): In Vivo Fast Ultrasound Super-Resolution Imaging using Nanodroplets

Super-Resolution Ultrasound Image Filtering with Machine-Learning to Reduce the Localization Error

Minimization of Nanodroplet Activation Time using Focused-Pulses for Droplet-Based Ultrasound Super-Resolution Imaging

Photoacoustic Super-Resolution Imaging using Laser Activation of Low-Boiling-Point Dye-Coated Nanodroplets in vitro and in vivo

Activation and 3D Imaging of Phase-change Nanodroplet Contrast Agents with a 2D Ultrasound Probe
